In such a manner, a light-emitting state of the backlight can be selected from (n+1) kinds of state: a non-light emission state and n kinds of light emission state. Note that the number of levels of brightness of the backlight can be reduced when N>n is satisfied; thus, manufacturing cost of the backlight and a driver circuit of the backlight can be reduced. In this embodiment mode, the case of N>n is described.
  • Among the levels of brightness of the backlight, brightness in the brightest state is denoted by L. Brightness Lk which is the k-th brightest state in order of increasing brightness can be brightness as shown in Formula 1 below.
  • L k = k n  L [ Formula   1 ]
  • In this embodiment mode, k is an integer of 0 to n. That is, brightness of the backlight can be proportional to k.
  • Then, k by which the brightness Lk of the backlight is determined is decided. In order to decide k, in each unit region of the backlight, the maximum gray scale value (the maximum gray scale value in the unit region: referred to as Glm) among gray scale values of all the pixels included in the display panel region corresponding to the unit region is examined first. Note that Glm is an integer of 0 to (N−1). Then, a value of k is determined based on the range of the maximum gray scale value Glm in the unit region. The range is represented by the minimum value Gkmin and the maximum value Gkmax(Gkmin≤Glm≤Gkmax). The minimum value Gkmin and the maximum value Gkmax are given by Formulae 2 and 3 below.
  • G k   min = N n × ( k - 1 ) + 1 [ Formula   2 ] G k   max = N n × k [ Formula   3 ]
  • For example, when N=256 and n=1, k is 0 or 1. When Gm is in the range of −255 to 0, k is equal to 0. Here, Glm is an integer of 0 to 255, and thus, Glm which gives k=0 is only 0. At this time, brightness of the backlight is preferably Lk=0 in accordance with Formula 1. That is, when the maximum gray scale value Glm in the unit region is 0, brightness of the unit region is preferably 0 (non-light emission). On the other hand, when Glm is in the range of 1 to 256, k is equal to 1. Here, Glm is an integer of 0 to 255, and thus, Glm which gives k=1 is in the range of 1≤Glm≤255. At this time, brightness of the backlight is preferably Lk=L in accordance with Formula 1.
  • Methods of setting brightness of a backlight in accordance with a gray scale value included in image data are largely classified into a method where the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is set to be 1 and a method where the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is set to be more than 1. In other words, the method where the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is set to be 1 is a method where states of brightness of the backlight are two states of non-light emission and light emission. Accordingly, the unit region of the backlight is in a non-light emission state only when the maximum gray scale value Glm in the unit region is 0 (when all of gray scale values of pixels in the unit region are 0), and a driving method for performing normal display can be employed except when the maximum gray scale value Glm in the unit region is 0. This driving method can prevent black blurring when black is displayed; thus, a contrast ratio can be improved. Further, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, display with reduced motion blur can be obtained as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio.
  • In contrast, in the method where the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is set to be more than 1, more various driving methods can be employed. For example, when N=256 and n=2, the number of gray scales to be displayed can be as large as approximately 1.5 times. This is because when k=2 and brightness of the backlight is Lk=L, brightness with 256 levels can be displayed, and when k=1 and brightness of the backlight is Lk=L/2, brightness which cannot be displayed in the case of Lk=L can be displayed. Specifically, brightness with 256 levels can be displayed on the lower gray scale side of half of the maximum brightness (in the range of the gray scale level of 0 to 127); thus, brightness with 384 levels obtained by (256 (the lower gray scale level side)+128 (the higher gray scale level side)) can be displayed as a whole. A human eye is particularly sensitive to difference of brightness on the lower gray scale level side. Accordingly, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side can be minutely expressed by this driving method; thus, image quality can be further improved particularly when images which mainly include dark images (e.g., a movie) are displayed. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is minutely expressed as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio, and display with reduced motion blur can be obtained.
  • In addition, when the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is increased, the number of gray scales to be displayed can be further increased. In general, the number Gn of gray scales which can be displayed when the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is n satisfies Formula 4 below.
  • G n = ∑ s = 1 n  N s [ Formula   4 ]
  • The reason is as follows. In the case of k=1, the number of gray scales which can be displayed is N. In the case of k=2, the number of gray scales which can be additionally displayed without overlapping with the gray scales in the case of k=1 is N/2. In the case of k=3, the number of gray scales which can be additionally displayed without overlapping with the gray scales in the cases of k=1 and k=2 is N/3. In the case of k=s, the number of gray scales which can be additionally displayed without overlapping with the gray scales in the cases of k=1 to k=(s−1) is N/s. In the case of k=n, the number of gray scales which can be additionally displayed without overlapping with the gray scales in the case of k=1 to k=(n−1) is N/n. Therefore, the number of gray scales as a whole is the sum of the number of gray scales which can be additionally displayed in respective values of k (see FIG. 3A: note that FIG. 3A illustrates the case of n=3). In this embodiment mode, s is an integer of 1 to n.
  • Specifically, in the case of n=3, the number of gray scales to be displayed is (1+½+⅓) times of N, that is, 1.83 times of N. In the case of n=4, the number of gray scales to be displayed is (1+½+⅓+¼) times of N, that is, 2.08 times of N. In the case of n=5, the number of gray scales to be displayed is (1+½+⅓+¼+⅕) times of N, that is, 2.28 times of N. In the case of n=6, the number of gray scales to be displayed is (1+½+⅓+¼+⅕+⅙) times of N, that is, 2.45 times of N. In the case of n=7, the number of gray scales to be displayed is (1+½+⅓+¼+⅕+⅙+ 1/7) times of N, that is, 2.59 times of N. In the case of n=8, the number of gray scales to be displayed is (1+½+⅓+¼+⅕+⅙+ 1/7+⅛) times of N, that is, 2.72 times of N. Although other cases are not shown, calculation can be performed in a similar manner. A gray scale on the lower gray scale level side can be more minutely expressed by increasing the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight; thus, image quality can be further improved particularly when images which mainly include dark images (e.g., a movie) are displayed. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio, and display with reduced motion blur can be obtained.
  • As another specific example, in the case of N=256 and n=8, that is, in the case of 256 levels (8 bits) of gray scale values included in image data and 8 levels of brightness of the backlight, a relation between the maximum gray scale value Glm in the unit region and brightness of the backlight is preferably set by Formulae 1 to 3 as follows. In the case of Glm=0, Lk=0 is preferable. In the case of 1≤Glm≤32, Lk=L/8 is preferable. In the case of 33≤Glm≤64, Lk=2L/8(L/4) is preferable. In the case of 65≤Glm≤96, Lk=3L/8 is preferable. In the case of 97≤Glm≤128, Lk=4L/8(L/2) is preferable. In the case of 129≤Glm≤160, Lk=5L/8 is preferable. In the case of 161≤Glm≤192, Lk=6L/8(2L/3) is preferable. In the case of 193≤Glm≤224, Lk=7L/8 is preferable. In the case of 225≤Glm≤255, Lk=8L/8(L) is preferable. In such a manner, when gray scale values included in image data are 256 levels (8 bits) and the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 8, the number of gray scales to be displayed can be approximately 696 levels by Formula 4. Further, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side can be more minutely expressed; thus, image quality can be further improved particularly when images which mainly include dark images (e.g., a movie) are displayed. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio, and display with reduced motion blur can be obtained.
  • As another specific example, in the case of N=1024 and n=8, that is, in the case of 1024 levels (10 bits) of gray scale values included in image data and 8 levels of brightness of the backlight, a relation between the maximum gray scale value Glm in the unit region and brightness of the backlight is preferably set by Formulae 1 to 3 as follows. In the case of Glm=0, Lk=0 is preferable. In the case of 1≤Glm≤128, Lk=L/8 is preferable. In the case of 129≤Glm≤256, Lk=2L/8(L/4) is preferable. In the case of 257≤Glm≤384, Lk=3L/8 is preferable. In the case of 385≤Glm≤512, Lk=4L/8(L/2) is preferable. In the case of 513≤Glm≤640, Lk=5L/8 is preferable. In the case of 641≤Glm≤768, Lk=6L/8(2L/3) is preferable. In the case of 769≤Glm≤896, Lk=7L/8 is preferable. In the case of 897≤Glm≤1023, Lk=8L/8(L) is preferable. In such a manner, when gray scale values included in image data are 1024 levels (10 bits) and the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 8, the number of gray scales to be displayed can be approximately 2785 levels by Formula 4. Further, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side can be more minutely expressed; thus, image quality can be further improved particularly when images which mainly include dark images (e.g., a movie) are displayed. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio, and display with reduced motion blur can be obtained.
  • Next, another method of setting brightness of a backlight in accordance with a gray scale value included in image data is described. Although brightness in the brightest state among the levels of brightness of the backlight is denoted by L in the above description, L can be changed in accordance with a gray scale value included in image data. Specifically, L can be increased as an average value of brightness in one image is reduced (see FIG. 3B), and L can be reduced as an average value of brightness in one image is increased (see FIG. 3C). Accordingly, in a bright image having a dark portion, a bright portion can be displayed more clearly. In contrast, in a generally-bright image, glare due to the general brightness can be reduced. That is, in such a manner, contrast of images in terms of sense can be improved; thus, image quality can be further improved, and glare can be reduced. Accordingly, eye-friendly display can be performed. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, display with reduced motion blur can be obtained as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio. Furthermore, when the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is increased, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed, and thus image quality can be further improved.
  • In addition, a state of brightness of each unit region included in the backlight can be set in accordance with not only a gray scale value included in image data but also a relation with brightness between unit regions of the backlight (see FIGS. 4A and 4B). FIG. 4A illustrates an image displayed on a display panel. FIG. 4B illustrates a light-emitting state of a backlight corresponding to the display panel shown in FIG. 4A.
  • An image 401 displayed on the display panel shown in FIG. 4A includes an object 402 and a background 403. At this time, among unit regions included in the backlight, only unit regions X4Y4, X5Y4, X4Y5, and X5Y5 (a center portion) may emit light, and the other unit regions may be in a non-light emission state depending on gray scale values included in image data. In this case, a dark portion in the image can be displayed as being darker and a bright portion in the image can be displayed as being brighter; thus, a contrast ratio can be improved. On the other hand, as shown in FIG. 4B, when a state of brightness of each unit region included in the backlight is set in accordance with a relation with brightness between unit regions included in the backlight, the center portion emits light, and X4Y3, X5Y3, X3Y4, X3Y5, X6Y4, X6Y5, X4Y6, and X5Y6 (a first peripheral portion) which are unit regions around the center portion emit light with lower brightness than the brightness of the center portion. Further, X4Y2, X5Y2, X3Y3, X6Y3, X2Y4, X7Y4, X2Y5, X7Y5, X3Y6, X6Y6, X4Y7, and X5Y7 (a second peripheral portion) which are unit regions around the first peripheral portion may emit light with lower brightness than the brightness of the first peripheral portion. Furthermore, brightness of unit regions around the second peripheral portion (a third peripheral portion) and unit regions around the third peripheral portion (a fourth peripheral portion) can be controlled in a similar manner. Other peripheral portions are similar in this respect. As described above, when there is difference exceeding a certain threshold value in brightness of adjacent unit regions of the backlight, the brightness of the adjacent unit regions can be controlled so that the difference is not larger than the threshold value. Accordingly, a phenomenon that a boundary of the unit region stands out in a portion where difference in brightness is large can be avoided, and smooth display can be performed. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, display with reduced motion blur can be obtained as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio and a phenomenon that a boundary of the unit region stands out can be avoided. Furthermore, when the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is increased, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed, and thus image quality can be further improved.
  • Next, a relation between brightness to be displayed and voltage applied to each pixel included in the display panel is described. When the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 1, light-emitting states of the backlight are two kinds of state: non-light emission and light emission. A unit region whose brightness to be displayed is 0 is made in a non-light emission state, and the other unit regions emit light. At this time, voltage applied to each pixel included in the display panel may be a value in accordance with image data or overdrive voltage obtained from the image data. When the voltage applied to each pixel included in the display panel is a value in accordance with the image data, a driver circuit of a display device can be simplified; thus, manufacturing cost and power consumption can be reduced. In contrast, when the voltage applied to each pixel included in the display panel is overdrive voltage, response time of a display element can be reduced; thus, image defects which occurs when moving images are displayed, such as afterimages, a phenomenon that traces are seen, and ghosting can be reduced.
  • Although detailed description of overdriving is omitted, overdriving is effective in improving quality of moving images, particularly in a display device in which a liquid crystal element is used. Specifically, overdriving is a driving method in which response time of the liquid crystal element is reduced by temporarily applying higher voltage than voltage which provides original transmittance. The voltage which is temporarily applied and higher than voltage providing original transmittance is referred to as overdrive voltage.
  • Then, the case where the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 2 or more is considered. The number of levels of brightness to be displayed can be increased as brightness of the background is lower as described above, and attention is needed when overdriving is performed in this case. Specifically, in normal overdriving, overdrive voltage is obtained in accordance with image data input to the display device; in contrast, in the case where the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 2 or more, overdrive voltage is obtained from a gray scale value (or a voltage value) which is actually written to the display panel, not from the image data input to the display device itself. For example, the case of N=256 and n=2, that is, the case where gray scale values included in image data are 256 levels (8 bits) and the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is 3 (non-light emission, moderate brightness, and the maximum brightness) is considered. When the brightness of the backlight is moderate in particular, and for example, when the gray scale level of 51 of the image data is displayed, a gray scale value on the display panel side can be 102, and the brightness of the backlight can be L/2. At this time, not the gray scale level (51) of the image data but the gray scale value (102) on the display panel side is preferably used as data for obtaining overdrive voltage. This is because the gray scale value of 102 is actually given to the display panel. Therefore, when the gray scale level of 51 of the image data is used for overdrive voltage, the obtained overdrive voltage and optimal overdrive voltage vary.
  • That is, when the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 2 or more, information on not only the gray scale value of the image data but also the gray scale value (or the voltage value) which is actually written to the display panel is needed to obtain the optimal overdrive voltage. Therefore, in a display device in which the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight can be 2 or more, a circuit for performing overdriving (an overdrive circuit) may have a structure in which information on brightness of the backlight or the gray scale value (or the voltage value) which is actually written to the display panel is input. Accordingly, in the display device in which the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 2 or more, appropriate overdrive voltage can be obtained. Thus, even in a display device in which an element whose response time is long, such as a liquid crystal element, is used, quality of moving images can be improved. Moreover, when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, display with reduced motion blur can be obtained as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio. Further, when the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is increased, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed, and thus image quality can be further improved. Furthermore, when brightness of unit regions of the backlight is controlled depending on difference in brightness of the unit regions of the backlight, a phenomenon that a boundary of the unit region stands out can be avoided.
  • Note that when driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other, the display panel may perform inversion driving in synchronization with the driving frequencies. This is effective in using source line inversion or gate line inversion, for example, because flickers are relatively noticeable in these driving methods. Accordingly, frequency of inversion driving can be increased, so that flickers in the display panel can be reduced. As specific values, when a frame rate of image data to be input is 60 Hz and the driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are 120 Hz, the frequency of inversion driving can be 60 Hz (synchronization). The operation that the frequency of inversion driving is synchronized with the driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight refers to a state in which positive voltage is written to a pixel, and thereafter, negative voltage is written for the next writing, and positive voltage is written for the next writing. When a liquid crystal element is used in a display device, such an operation can prevent direct-current voltage from being applied to the liquid crystal element; thus, the life of the liquid crystal element can be increased, and flickers can be reduced.
  • Alternatively, inversion driving of the display panel is not necessarily synchronized with the driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight. Specifically, the driving frequency of inversion driving of the display panel can be frequency obtained by dividing the driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight by an integer. This is effective in using dot inversion, for example, because dot inversion can effectively reduce flickers even when the driving frequency is relatively low. Accordingly, the driving frequency of inversion driving of the display panel can be reduced, so that power consumption can be reduced. As specific values, when a frame rate of image data to be input is 60 Hz and the driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are 120 Hz, the frequency of inversion driving can be 30 Hz (half). The operation that the frequency of inversion driving is half the driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight refers to a state in which positive voltage is written to a pixel, and thereafter, positive voltage is also written for the next writing, and then, negative voltage is written for the next writing, and negative voltage is also written for the next writing, and then, positive voltage is written for the next writing. When a liquid crystal element is used in a display device, such an operation can prevent direct-current voltage from being applied to the liquid crystal element; thus, the life of the liquid crystal element can be increased, and flickers can be reduced. Moreover, power consumption can be reduced.
  • Note that a division state of the backlight described in this embodiment mode can be a variety of states in addition to a rectangle. As the number of division is increased, brightness of the backlight can be controlled more minutely; thus, image quality can be improved. On the other hand, as the number of division is reduced, the number of unit regions to be controlled is reduced; thus, manufacturing cost can be reduced.
  • Several special division states among division states of the backlight are described. First, in the cases where the area of the backlight is divided into rectangular shapes, the case where the number of division in either the lateral direction or the horizontal direction is 1 is described with reference to FIGS. 5A and 5B. FIG. 5A illustrates an example of a light-emitting state of a backlight at this time. FIG. 5B illustrates an image displayed on a display panel at this time. A light-emitting region 501 is in a light-emitting state in accordance with an image 502. The image 502 includes an object 503 and a background 504. A variety of methods described above can be used as the method of setting brightness of a backlight in accordance with a gray scale value included in image data. For example, L can be increased as an average value of brightness in one image is reduced, and L can be reduced as an average value of brightness in one image is increased. When driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, display with reduced motion blur can be obtained as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio. Further, when the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is increased, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed, and thus image quality can be further improved. Furthermore, when brightness of unit regions of the backlight is controlled depending on difference in brightness of the unit regions, a phenomenon that a boundary of the unit region stands out can be avoided. Further, when overdrive voltage is obtained in accordance with a gray scale value which is actually input to the display panel, appropriate overdrive voltage can be obtained even in a display device in which the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 2 or more. Thus, even in a display device in which an element whose response time is long, such as a liquid crystal element, is used, quality of moving images can be improved. Note that it is preferable to divide the area of the backlight so that the divided areas are in parallel to a gate line in the display panel. Accordingly, driving of the backlight can be synchronized with driving of the display panel as appropriate; thus, image defects such as ghosting can be reduced.
  • Next, in cases where the area of the backlight is divided into rectangular shapes, the case where the number of division in both the lateral direction and the horizontal direction is 1 is described with reference to FIGS. 6A and 6B. FIG. 6A illustrates an example of a light-emitting state of a backlight at this time. FIG. 6B illustrates an image displayed on a display panel at this time. A light-emitting region 511 is in a light-emitting state in accordance with an image 512. The image 512 includes an object 513 (gray scale level of 254) and a background 514 (gray scale level of 0). A variety of methods described above can be used as the method of setting brightness of a backlight in accordance with a gray scale value included in image data. For example, L can be increased as an average value of brightness in one image is reduced, and L can be reduced as an average value of brightness in one image is increased. When driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight are synchronized with each other while this driving method is performed, display with reduced motion blur can be obtained as well as still images have a higher contrast ratio. Further, when the number of levels of brightness of the backlight is increased, a gray scale on the lower gray scale level side is more minutely expressed, and thus image quality can be further improved. Furthermore, when overdrive voltage is obtained in accordance with a gray scale value which is actually input to the display panel, appropriate overdrive voltage can be obtained even in a display device in which the number n of levels of brightness of the backlight is 2 or more. Thus, even in a display device in which an element whose response time is long, such as a liquid crystal element, is used, quality of moving images can be improved.
  • Next, a circuit structure for realizing the driving method in this embodiment mode is described with reference to FIGS. 7, 8, 9A, 9B, and 10. A display device in this embodiment mode includes a display panel and a backlight, and can also include a circuit for driving the display panel or the backlight. For example, as shown in FIG. 7, the display device can include a display panel 601, a backlight 602, a display panel control circuit 603, a backlight control circuit 604, and a data processing circuit 605. The display panel control circuit 603 is a circuit for controlling the display panel 601. The backlight control circuit 604 is a circuit for controlling the backlight 602. The data processing circuit 605 performs data processing for inputting a variety of signals (in this embodiment mode, a control signal and image data) which are input to the display device to the display panel control circuit 603 and the backlight control circuit 604.
  • The display panel control circuit 603 can include a timing controller 701, a source driver (or a data driver) 702, and a gate driver (or a scan driver) 703 (see FIG. 8). Image data for the display panel and a display panel frequency control signal which are output from the data processing circuit 605 are input as display panel input signals to the display panel control circuit 603. The display panel input signals are input to the timing controller 701. The timing controller 701 transmits image data for the source driver and a source driver control signal to the source driver 702 in accordance with the display panel input signals. Moreover, the timing controller 701 transmits a gate driver control signal to the gate driver 703 in accordance with the display panel input signals. A source line included in the display panel is driven by the source driver 702 in accordance with the control of the timing controller 701. The gate line included in the display panel is driven by the gate driver 703 in accordance with the control of the timing controller 701.
  • The structure of the backlight control circuit 604 can be selected depending on a method of driving the backlight. For example, when each unit region included in the backlight 602 is directly controlled, the backlight control circuit 604 can include a backlight controller 801 and (i×j) numbers of backlight driver circuits 802 (see FIG. 9A). In this case, image data for the backlight and a backlight frequency control signal which are output from the data processing circuit 605 are input as backlight input signals to the backlight control circuit 604. The backlight input signals are input to the backlight controller 801. The backlight controller 801 transmits a backlight driver circuit control signal to each of the (i×j) numbers of backlight driver circuits 802 in accordance with the backlight input signals. Unit regions included in the backlight 602 are driven by the (i×j) numbers of backlight driver circuits 802, and the (i×j) numbers of backlight driver circuits 802 decide a light-emitting state of each unit region. An advantage in the case where each unit region included in the backlight 602 is directly controlled in such a manner is that each unit region included in the backlight 602 can be individually controlled, and thus there is a lot of flexibility of driving. For example, all the unit regions can be driven at the same time, the unit regions can be driven and synchronized with driving of the display panel, and a given unit region can be controlled in a different manner than the other unit regions. Moreover, such unlimited control can be selected as appropriate depending on a driving state of the display panel, surroundings, user setting, and the like.
  • In addition, for example, a structure in which unit regions included in the backlight 602 are sequentially selected and a driving state of each unit regions is written (active matrix) can be employed. In this case, the backlight control circuit 604 can include a backlight controller 811, a backlight data driver 812, and a backlight scan driver 813 (see FIG. 9B). In this case, image data for the backlight and a backlight frequency control signal which are output from the data processing circuit 605 are input as backlight input signals to the backlight control circuit 604. The backlight input signals are input to the backlight controller 811. The backlight controller 811 transmits image data for the backlight data driver and a backlight data driver control signal to the backlight data driver 812 in accordance with the backlight input signals. Moreover, the backlight controller 811 transmits a backlight scan driver control signal to the backlight scan driver 813 in accordance with the backlight input signals. A data line included in the backlight is driven by the backlight data driver 812 in accordance with control of the backlight controller 811. A scan line included in the backlight is driven by the backlight scan driver 813 in accordance with control of the backlight controller 811. Further, in this case, each unit region included in the backlight can include a memory element. Thus, a light-emitting state of each unit region can be stored at least in a driving cycle of the backlight. An advantage of driving the unit regions included in the backlight by active matrix in such a manner is improvement in reliability of the device due to a small number of connection wirings, which leads to reduction in area of a frame of the backlight (a periphery portion of the light-emitting region). Moreover, in the case of an active matrix display device, driving methods can be unified; thus, driving frequencies of the display panel and the backlight can be easily synchronized with each other.
  • The data processing circuit 605 performs processing of the control signal and the image data which are input to the display device so that the control signal and the image data are in a state capable of being treated in the display panel control circuit 603 and the backlight control circuit 604. Moreover, the data processing circuit 605 can be provided with a variety of additional functions, for example, a function of matching an input signal to the display device and a signal treated in the data processing circuit 605, a function of generating an intermediate image by motion compensation, a function of synchronizing driving frequencies of the display panel control circuit 603 and the backlight control circuit 604 with each other, and a function of converting the image data for the display panel into image data for overdriving. The data processing circuit 605 having such functions can include an interface circuit 901, a movement estimation circuit 902, a memory 903, an image generation circuit 904, a frequency conversion circuit 905, an image data generation circuit for the backlight 906, a gray scale data conversion circuit 907, a lookup table (LUT) 908, and a memory 909 (see FIG. 10).
  • A variety of signals (in this embodiment mode, a control signal and image data) which are input to the display device are input to the data processing circuit 605. The signals are input to the interface circuit 901. The interface circuit 901 performs processing to match the signals and the signal treated in the data processing circuit 605, for example, processing to format image data in accordance with a vertical synchronization signal and a horizontal synchronization signal and processing to step up or down voltage of the signal. The interface circuit 901 transmits the image data to the movement estimation circuit 902, the memory 903, and the frequency conversion circuit 905. Moreover, the interface circuit 901 may transmit a frequency control signal to the frequency conversion circuit 905.
  • The memory 903 is for transmitting delayed image data to the movement estimation circuit 902. The movement estimation circuit 902 is a circuit for detecting movement of images from the image data transmitted from the interface circuit 901 and the delayed image data transmitted from the memory 903. The movement estimation circuit 902 transmits information on the movement of the images to the image generation circuit 904. The image generation circuit 904 is a circuit for generating intermediate image data from the information on the movement of the images transmitted from the movement estimation circuit 902. The image generation circuit 904 transmits the generated intermediate image data to the frequency conversion circuit 905.
  • The frequency conversion circuit 905 is a circuit for arranging the image data transmitted from the interface circuit 901 and the intermediate image data transmitted from the image generation circuit 904 in predetermined order and converting frequency. For example, when the image data transmitted from the interface circuit 901 and the intermediate image data transmitted from the image generation circuit 904 are alternately arranged, the frequency of data output from the frequency conversion circuit 905 can be twice the frequency of each input signal. Then, the frequency conversion circuit 905 transmits the image data whose frequency has been converted to the image data generation circuit for the backlight 906, the gray scale data conversion circuit 907, and the memory 909. Moreover, the frequency conversion circuit 905 may transmit a backlight frequency control signal and a display panel frequency control signal to the backlight control circuit 604 and the display panel control circuit 603.
  • The image data generation circuit for the backlight 906 generates image data for the backlight from the image data transmitted from the frequency conversion circuit 905. As a method of generating image data for the backlight, the method described in this embodiment mode can be used.
  • The memory 909 is for transmitting the delayed image data to the gray scale data conversion circuit 907. The gray scale data conversion circuit 907 is a circuit for converting the image data transmitted from the frequency conversion circuit 905 and the image data transmitted from the memory 909 into image data for overdriving. Although detailed description of a conversion method is omitted, the gray scale data conversion circuit 907 can have a structure in which conversion is performed with the image data transmitted from the frequency conversion circuit 905 and the image data transmitted from the memory 909 by referring to the LUT 908. Alternatively, the gray scale data conversion circuit 907 may have a structure in which the image data is processed by a logic circuit such as a subtractor, a multiplier, and an adder, without using the LUT 908. Accordingly, a memory forming the LUT 908 can be reduced; thus, manufacturing cost can be reduced. Similarly, from a viewpoint of reduction in memory, the memory 903 and the memory 909 can be used in common. Further, when an encoder and a decoder are provided input and output sides of the memory 909, the size of the memory 909 can be reduced.
  • Note that the structure of the above-described driver circuit is an example, and each circuit is not necessarily used as its component. Therefore, when a part of the circuits is omitted or overlaps with each other or when a part of the functions is added or changed, such a device can be used as a display device according to this embodiment mode.
  • Note that in the backlight in this embodiment mode, an organic EL element can be used as a light-emitting element. In this case, the light-emitting element with a large area can be formed at low cost by a coating method, a droplet discharging method, and the like. Moreover, in the backlight in this embodiment mode, an inorganic EL element can be used as a light-emitting element. In this case, the light-emitting element with less deterioration and high output can be obtained.
  • Note that although this embodiment mode is described with reference to various drawings, the contents (or part of the contents) described in each drawing can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with the contents (or part of the contents) described in another drawing. Further, much more drawings can be formed by combining each part with another part in the above-described drawings.
  • Similarly, the contents (or part of the contents) described in each drawing in this embodiment mode can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with the contents (or part of the contents) described in a drawing in another embodiment mode. Further, much more drawings can be formed by combining each part in each drawing in this embodiment mode with part of another embodiment mode.
  • Note that this embodiment mode shows examples of embodying, slightly transforming, partially modifying, improving, describing in detail, or applying the contents (or part of the contents) described in another embodiment mode, an example of related part thereof, or the like. Therefore, the contents described in another embodiment mode can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with this embodiment mode.
    • Embodiment Mode 2
  • In this embodiment mode, among methods of improving quality of images displayed on a display device, an example which is different from the method described in Embodiment Mode 1 is described. Specifically, a method of improving quality of images displayed on a display device by using a backlight is described. More specifically, a method of providing a period for displaying a blank image in addition to an image in accordance with image data input to the display device as images displayed on a display panel, and a method in which the area of a backlight is divided into a plurality of regions and brightness of each of the plurality of regions is controlled in accordance with image data to be displayed are described.
  • Here, a blank image is an image whose brightness is the same in the whole display region. Note that a blank image in this embodiment mode can be displayed by a display panel or a backlight. Examples of the blank image include a black image in which black is displayed on the whole display region, a gray image with moderate brightness in the whole display region, and a white image with the maximum brightness in the whole display region. It is needless to say that the blank image can be a color image by controlling brightness of RGB of the blank image.
  • A backlight and a display panel in the method described in this embodiment mode can be the backlight and the display panel described in Embodiment Mode 1. Although detailed description is omitted, characteristics and advantages of use of such backlight and display device are similar to those described in Embodiment Mode 1.
  • First, an image in this embodiment mode, which is displayed on an image display region of the display panel, is described. The image displayed on the image display region has a period during which the image is displayed in accordance with image data to be input. The image data to be input has a given cycle, and an image displayed on the image display region is rewritten in accordance with the cycle. FIG. 11B illustrates change of the image displayed on the image display region with time passing. In the display panel shown in FIG. 11B, an image 1011 is displayed at a certain point. Then, after the cycle Tin of the image data to be input passes, an image 1017 is displayed. That is, FIG. 11B illustrates change with time of images to be displayed on the image display region, with time represented by the horizontal axis.
  • In the method described in this embodiment mode, another image is displayed while the image is changed from the image 1011 to the image 1017, similarly to Embodiment Mode 1. Specifically, an image 1014 can be displayed as shown in FIG. 11B. In this embodiment mode, the image 1014 is a blank image. The image 1014 is displayed at the time when a period obtained by multiplication of the cycle Tin of image data to be input by ½ passes after the image 1011 is displayed. Note that the image 1014 can be displayed at a variety of timings without being limited thereto, and detailed description is omitted.
  • Next, images displayed on the image display region of the display panel are described in detail. The image 1011 which is displayed first includes an object 1012 and a background 1013. The image 1014 which is displayed next is the blank image. The image 1017 which is displayed next includes an object 1018 and a background 1019. In this embodiment mode, each of the images 1011 and 1017 is an image displayed in accordance with image data input to the display device.
  • In a method where the image 1011 continues to be displayed without another image being displayed while the image is changed from the image 1011 to the image 1017, the image 1011 continues to be displayed in a period of the cycle Tin of the image data to be input after the image 1011 is displayed, and the image 1017 is displayed at the time when the cycle Tin of the image data to be input passes. At this time, eyes of a human who sees a displayed image tend to follow movement of the object while the human predicts that the object keeps moving. Thus, a discrepancy occurs between tracking of the object by the human eyes and the displayed image, and the human eyes perceive a blurred image.
  • On the other hand, in the method described in this embodiment mode, the image 1014 which is the blank image is displayed at the time when a period obtained by multiplication of the cycle Tin of the image data to be input by ½ passes after the image 1011 is displayed; thus, the discrepancy between tracking of the object by the human eyes and the displayed image can be reduced, and blurring of the image can be prevented from being perceived. Thus, motion blur due to a hold-type display device can be reduced, and quality of display images, especially moving images can be improved.
  • In addition, in the method described in this embodiment mode, a light-emitting region of the backlight is divided into a plurality of unit regions, and brightness of each unit region can be individually controlled; thus, quality of display images can be further improved. Specifically, when brightness of each unit region included in the backlight is individually controlled in accordance with an image displayed on the display panel, a dark portion in the image can be displayed as being darker and a bright portion in the image can be displayed as being brighter (a contrast ratio can be improved). This is particularly effective when a liquid crystal element is used in the display panel, for example. This is because the display panel in which the liquid crystal element is used slightly transmits light of the backlight when black is displayed. That is, even if the liquid crystal element is controlled so that black is displayed, light of the backlight is leaked when the backlight emits light. Accordingly, light is emitted slightly, and thus, black cannot be displayed as sheer black. This phenomenon is referred to as black blurring.
  • By using the method described in this embodiment mode, black blurring can be reduced. This is because when light is not emitted in a unit region of the backlight corresponding to a portion in which the liquid crystal element is controlled so that black is displayed, black blurring in the unit region can be avoided. Accordingly, the contrast ratio can be improved.
  • Note that a phenomenon of black blurring does not occur only in a liquid crystal display device. A phenomenon that black is not displayed as “black” likely occurs in any display device. In the method shown in this embodiment mode, light emission of a light-emitting element is stopped when black is displayed, and the method shown in this embodiment mode can be applied to a variety of display devices without being limited to a liquid crystal display device.
  • Further, in the method described in this embodiment mode, individual control of brightness of the unit regions included in the backlight is performed in synchronization with the cycle Tin of the image data to be input as well as the blank image is included as images displayed on the image display region of the display panel; thus, a special effect can be obtained. That is, both reduction in motion blur by including the blank image as the images of the display panel and improvement in contrast ratio by performing individual control of brightness of the unit regions included in the backlight in accordance with the image data can be realized, and moreover, frequency of driving the backlight can be half of frequency of driving the display panel; thus, reduction in power consumption can be realized at the same time.
  • Although detailed description is omitted, a variety of driving frequencies can be used as the driving frequency of the display panel without being limited to double-frame rate driving. For example, rational number multiple of the driving frequency, such as 3/2-fold frame rate driving, 4/3-fold frame rate driving, or 5/2-fold frame rate driving as well as integer multiple of the driving frequency, such as triple-frame rate driving, quadruple-frame rate driving, 5-fold frame rate driving, 6-fold frame rate driving, 7-fold frame rate driving, or 8-fold frame rate driving can be employed. In the case of any driving frequency, the frequency of driving the backlight is less than the frequency of driving the display panel; thus, power consumption can be reduced.
  • A method in which brightness of each unit region included in a backlight is controlled while a blank image is displayed on a display panel is described with reference to FIGS. 11A and 11B. FIG. 11A illustrates a state of change in brightness of unit regions of the backlight with time represented by the horizontal axis, similarly to FIG. 11B. For simplification, description is made on the assumption that the objects 1012 and 1018 are white or gray and the backgrounds 1013 and 1019 are black in the images 1011 and 1017, respectively.
  • First, in a light-emitting region 1001, a region 1002 (here, including unit regions X2Y3, X2Y4, X2Y5, X2Y6, X3Y3, X3Y4, X3Y5, X3Y6, X4Y3, X4Y4, X4Y5, and X4Y6) which is the position corresponding to the position of the object 1012 emits light, and the other region 1003 does not emit light. Accordingly, black blurring of the background 1013 can be prevented, and the object 1012 can be displayed as being bright; thus, a contrast ratio can be improved. Thereafter, the blank image is displayed on the display panel, and a light-emitting state of the unit regions of the backlight is not changed. Then, a region 1008 (here, including unit regions X4Y3, X4Y4, X4Y5, X4Y6, X5Y3, X5Y4, X5Y5, X5Y6, X6Y3, X6Y4, X6Y5, and X6Y6) which is the position corresponding to the position of the object 1018 emits light, and the other region 1009 does not emit light. In such a manner, brightness of each unit region included in the backlight can be controlled while the blank image is displayed on the display panel.
  • Next, timing of driving a backlight and a display panel is described in detail with reference to FIGS. 12A to 12D. FIGS. 12A and 12C each illustrate timing of rewriting brightness of unit regions of the backlight. The horizontal axis represents time, and the vertical axis represents the vertical position of the backlight. FIGS. 12B and 12D each illustrate timing of rewriting transmittance of the display panel. The horizontal axis represents time, and the vertical axis represents the vertical position of the display panel. Note that the timing of driving the backlight shown in FIG. 12A is performed in combination with the timing of driving the display panel shown in FIG. 12B. Similarly, the timing of driving the backlight shown in FIG. 12C is performed in combination with the timing of driving the display panel shown in FIG. 12D.
  • In FIGS. 12A and 12C, a light-emitting state of each unit region of the backlight is rewritten at the timing shown by a solid line. In this embodiment mode, rewriting is performed on unit regions with the same vertical positions at the same timing, regardless of the horizontal position (line sequential driving). Note that the invention is not limited thereto, and rewriting may sequentially performed in accordance with the horizontal positions (dot sequential driving). In particular, when rewriting is performed in the display panel with dot sequential driving, dot sequential driving is preferably performed on the unit regions of the backlight as well. Each of groups 1101, 1103, 1121, and 1123 is a collection in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten.
  • In FIG. 12A, as shown by the group 1101, a period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is half the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. This is because the backlight is driven in accordance with driving of the display panel shown in FIG. 12B. Note that as has been described above, the period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is not limited thereto, and a variety of periods can be used. Then, after rewriting shown by the group 1101 finishes, the backlight is not driven until a period of half the cycle Tin of the input image data passes. Then, rewriting shown by the group 1103 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • In FIG. 12C, as shown by the group 1121, a period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. This is because the backlight is driven in accordance with driving of the display panel shown in FIG. 12D. Note that as has been described above, the period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is not limited thereto, and a variety of periods can be used. Then, after rewriting shown by the group 1121 finishes, rewriting shown by the group 1123 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • In each of FIGS. 12B and 12D, transmittance of each pixel of the display panel is rewritten at the timing shown by a solid line. In this embodiment mode, rewriting is performed on pixels with the same vertical positions at the same timing, regardless of the horizontal position (line sequential driving). Note that the invention is not limited thereto as has been described above, and rewriting may be performed with dot sequential driving. In any case, it is important to match timings of rewriting the display panel and the backlight. Accordingly, difference between the states of the display panel and the backlight can be reduced; thus, defects of display, such as ghosting, can be reduced.
  • In FIG. 12B, a solid line 1111 schematically illustrates timing when all the pixels in the display panel are rewritten. To be exact, the timing should be stair shapes of the number of pixels in the vertical direction, similarly in FIG. 12A; however, in FIG. 12B, the timing is shown by the oblique line for simplification. In FIG. 12B, as shown by the solid line 1111, a cycle in which all the pixels of the display panel are rewritten is half the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. This is because the display panel is driven with double-frame rate driving in order to display the blank image. Note that as has been described above, the driving frequency is not limited thereto, and a variety of driving frequencies can be used. In any case, it is important to match timings of rewriting the display panel and the backlight. The reason is as described above. Then, after rewriting shown by the solid line 1111 finishes, rewriting shown by a solid line 1112 starts. Similarly, after rewriting shown by the solid line 1112 finishes, rewriting shown by a solid line 1113 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • In FIG. 12D, a solid line 1131 schematically illustrates timing when all the pixels in the display panel are rewritten. To be exact, the timing should be stair shapes of the number of pixels in the vertical direction, similarly in FIG. 12C; however, in FIG. 12D, the timing is shown by the oblique line for simplification. In FIG. 12D, as shown by the solid line 1131, a cycle in which all the pixels of the display panel are rewritten is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. However, the blank image can be displayed because driving shown by the solid line 1132 starts when a period of half the cycle Tin of the image data passes after driving shown by the solid line 1131 starts. Several methods can be considered to perform a plurality of different kinds of driving at the same time as shown in FIG. 12D. Examples of such a method include a method in which one gate selection period is divided into two periods and driving with different vertical positions is assigned in each period, and a method in which potentials of a plurality of pixels are set to be the same by a common power supply line in the case where an image to be displayed is the blank image. Accordingly, a plurality of different kinds of driving can be performed at the same time, so that driving shown in FIG. 12D can be realized. In the driving shown in FIG. 12D, an apparent cycle is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input, so that driving frequency can be reduced, and thus power consumption can be reduced. Note that as has been described above, the driving frequency is not limited thereto, and a variety of driving frequencies can be used. In any case, it is important to match timings of rewriting the display panel and the backlight. The reason is as described above. Then, after rewriting shown by the solid line 1131 finishes, rewriting shown by the solid line 1133 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • Note that in addition to the time when a period of half the cycle Tin of the input image data passes after driving shown by the solid line 1131 starts, the time when driving timing shown by the solid line 1132 in FIG. 12D starts can be a variety of timings, for example, the range shown by an arrow adjacent to the solid line 1132. The time when the driving timing shown by the solid line 1132 starts is preferably the time when a period of ¼ to ¾ times of the cycle Tin of the input image data passes after driving shown by the solid line 1131 starts. The time when the driving timing shown by the solid line 1132 starts is in this range, so that motion blur can be effectively reduced as well as flickers are reduced.
  • Note that whether timings of rewriting the backlight and the display panel correspond to each other can be determined from the fact that the solid line 1111 or 1131 crosses all of the solid lines included in the group 1101 or 1121 when FIGS. 12A and 12B or FIGS. 12C and 12D overlap with each other. It is important for the timings which can be said to correspond to each other to have a fixed range. In other words, since the timings of rewriting the backlight and the display panel have a fixed range of the timings which can be said to correspond to each other, it can be said that a margin in operation is large. That is, when the backlight and the display panel are operated at the timing shown in FIGS. 12A and 12B or FIGS. 12C and 12D, stability of the operation can be improved.
  • Note that although this embodiment mode is described with reference to various drawings, the contents (or part of the contents) described in each drawing can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with the contents (or part of the contents) described in another drawing. Further, much more drawings can be formed by combining each part with another part in the above-described drawings.
  • Similarly, the contents (or part of the contents) described in each drawing in this embodiment mode can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with the contents (or part of the contents) described in a drawing in another embodiment mode. Further, much more drawings can be formed by combining each part in each drawing in this embodiment mode with part of another embodiment mode.
  • Note that this embodiment mode shows examples of embodying, slightly transforming, partially modifying, improving, describing in detail, or applying the contents (or part of the contents) described in another embodiment mode, an example of related part thereof, or the like. Therefore, the contents described in another embodiment mode can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with this embodiment mode.
    • Embodiment Mode 3
  • In this embodiment mode, among methods of improving quality of images displayed on a display device, an example which is different from the methods described in Embodiment Modes 1 and 2 is described. Specifically, a method of improving quality of images displayed on a display device by using a backlight is described. More specifically, a method of providing a period for displaying a blank image in addition to an image in accordance with an image displayed on a display panel as images displayed on the backlight, and a method in which the area of a backlight is divided into a plurality of regions and brightness of each of the plurality of regions is controlled in accordance with image data to be displayed are described.
  • A backlight and a display panel in the method described in this embodiment mode can be the backlight and the display panel described in Embodiment Mode 1. Although detailed description is omitted, characteristics and advantages of use of such backlight and display device are similar to those described in Embodiment Mode 1.
  • First, an image in this embodiment mode, which is displayed on an image display region of the display panel, is described. The image displayed on the image display region of the display panel has a period during which the image is displayed in accordance with image data to be input. The image data to be input has a given cycle, and an image displayed on the image display region is rewritten in accordance with the cycle. FIG. 13B illustrates change of the image displayed on the image display region with time passing. In the display panel shown in FIG. 13B, an image 1211 is displayed at a certain point. Then, after the cycle Tin of the image data to be input passes, an image 1217 is displayed. That is, FIG. 13B illustrates change with time of images to be displayed on the image display region, with time represented by the horizontal axis.
  • In the method described in this embodiment mode, another image is not displayed and the image 1211 continues to be displayed while the image is changed from the image 1211 to the image 1217, which is different from Embodiment Modes 1 and 2, and a blank image is displayed on the backlight.
  • Next, the images displayed on the image display region of the display panel are described in detail. The image 1211 which is displayed first includes an object 1212 and a background 1213. An image 1214 which is displayed next includes an object 1215 and a background 1216, which are the same as the components in the image 1211. The image 1217 which is displayed next includes an object 1218 and a background 1219. In this embodiment mode, each of the images 1211 and 1217 is an image displayed in accordance with image data input to the display device.
  • Note that in the method described in this embodiment mode, although the image 1214 which is displayed when the time of half the cycle Tin of the image data to be input passes after the image 1211 is displayed is the same as the image 1211, the blank image is displayed on the backlight at that time; thus, an image which is actually perceived by human eyes corresponds to the blank image of the backlight. Particularly when the blank image of the backlight at that time is a black image, the image which is actually perceived by human eyes is a black image regardless of components in the image 1214. Thus, motion blur due to a hold-type display device can be reduced, and quality of display images, especially moving images can be improved.
  • In addition, in the method described in this embodiment mode, a light-emitting region of the backlight is divided into a plurality of unit regions, and brightness of each unit region can be individually controlled; thus, quality of display images can be further improved. Specifically, when brightness of each unit region included in the backlight is individually controlled in accordance with an image displayed on the display panel, a dark portion in the image can be displayed as being darker and a bright portion in the image can be displayed as being brighter (a contrast ratio can be improved). This is particularly effective when a liquid crystal element is used in the display panel. This is because in the display panel in which the liquid crystal element is used, black blurring occurs even when black is displayed.
  • By using the method described in this embodiment mode, black blurring can be reduced. This is because when light is not emitted in a unit region of the backlight corresponding to a portion in which the liquid crystal element is controlled so that black is displayed, black blurring in the unit region can be avoided. Accordingly, the contrast ratio can be improved.
  • Note that a phenomenon of black blurring does not occur only in a liquid crystal display device. A phenomenon that black is not displayed as “black” likely occurs in any display device. In the method shown in this embodiment mode, light emission of a light-emitting element is stopped when black is displayed, and the method shown in this embodiment mode can be applied to a variety of display devices without being limited to a liquid crystal display device.
  • Further, in the method described in this embodiment mode, control of the display panel is performed in synchronization with the cycle Tin of the image data to be input as well as the blank image is included as images displayed on the backlight; thus, a special effect can be obtained. That is, both reduction in motion blur by including the blank image as the images displayed on the backlight and improvement in contrast ratio by performing individual control of brightness of the unit regions included in the backlight in accordance with the image data can be realized, and moreover, frequency of driving the display panel can be half of frequency of driving the backlight; thus, reduction in power consumption can be realized at the same time.
  • Although detailed description is omitted, a variety of driving frequencies can be used as driving frequencies of the backlight and the display panel without being limited to double-frame rate driving. For example, rational number multiple of the driving frequency, such as 3/2-fold frame rate driving, 4/3-fold frame rate driving, or 5/2-fold frame rate driving as well as integer multiple of the driving frequency, such as triple-frame rate driving, quadruple-frame rate driving, 5-fold frame rate driving, 6-fold frame rate driving, 7-fold frame rate driving, or 8-fold frame rate driving can be employed. In the case of any driving frequency, frequency of driving the display panel is less than frequency of driving the backlight; thus, power consumption can be reduced.
  • A method in which brightness of each unit region included in a backlight is controlled while a blank image is displayed on the backlight is described with reference to FIGS. 13A and 13B. FIG. 13A illustrates a state of change in brightness of unit regions of the backlight with time represented by the horizontal axis, similarly to FIG. 13B. For simplification, description is made on the assumption that the objects 1212, 1215, and 1218 are white or gray and the backgrounds 1213, 1216, and 1219 are black in the images 1211, 1214, and 1217, respectively.
  • First, in a light-emitting region 1201, a region 1202 (here, including unit regions X2Y3, X2Y4, X2Y5, X2Y6, X3Y3, X3Y4, X3Y5, X3Y6, X4Y3, X4Y4, X4Y5, and X4Y6) which is the position corresponding to the position of the object 1212 emits light, and the other region 1203 does not emit light. Accordingly, black blurring of the background 1213 can be prevented, and the object 1212 can be displayed as being bright; thus, a contrast ratio can be improved. Thereafter, the blank image is displayed on the backlight, and the image displayed on the display panel is not changed. Then, a region 1208 (here, including unit regions X4Y3, X4Y4, X4Y5, X4Y6, X5Y3, X5Y4, X5Y5, X5Y6, X6Y3, X6Y4, X6Y5, and X6Y6) which is the position corresponding to the position of the object 1218 emits light, and the other region 1209 does not emit light. In such a manner, brightness of each unit region included in the backlight can be controlled as well as the blank image is displayed on the backlight.
  • Next, timing of driving a backlight and a display panel is described in detail with reference to FIGS. 14A to 14D. FIGS. 14A and 14C each illustrate timing of rewriting brightness of unit regions of the backlight. The horizontal axis represents time, and the vertical axis represents the vertical position of the backlight. FIGS. 14B and 14D each illustrate timing of rewriting transmittance of the display panel. The horizontal axis represents time; and the vertical axis represents the vertical position of the display panel. Note that the timing of driving the backlight shown in FIG. 14A is performed in combination with the timing of driving the display panel shown in FIG. 14B. Similarly, the timing of driving the backlight shown in FIG. 14C is performed in combination with the timing of driving the display panel shown in FIG. 14D.
  • In FIGS. 14A and 14C, a light-emitting state of each unit region of the backlight is rewritten at the timing shown by a solid line. In this embodiment mode, rewriting is performed on unit regions with the same vertical positions at the same timing, regardless of the horizontal position (line sequential driving). Note that the invention is not limited thereto, and rewriting may sequentially performed in accordance with the horizontal positions (dot sequential driving). In particular, when rewriting is performed in the display panel with dot sequential driving, dot sequential driving is preferably performed on the unit regions of the backlight as well. Each of groups 1301, 1302, 1303, 1321, 1322, and 1323 is a collection in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten.
  • In FIG. 14A, as shown by the group 1301, a period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is half the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. This is because the backlight is driven by double-frame rate driving in order to display the blank image. Note that as has been described above, the period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is not limited thereto, and a variety of periods can be used. Then, after rewriting shown by the group 1301 finishes, rewriting shown by the group 1302 starts. Then, after rewriting shown by the group 1302 finishes, rewriting shown by the group 1303 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • In FIG. 14C, as shown by the group 1321, a period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. However, the blank image can be displayed because driving shown by the group 1322 starts when a period of half the cycle Tin of the image data passes after driving shown by the group 1321 starts. Several methods can be considered to perform a plurality of different kinds of driving at the same time as shown in FIG. 14C. Examples of such a method include a method in which one gate selection period is divided into two periods and driving with different vertical positions is assigned in each period; and a method in which potentials of a plurality of pixels are set to be the same by a common power supply line in the case where an image to be displayed on the backlight is the blank image. Accordingly, a plurality of different kinds of driving can be performed at the same time, so that driving shown in FIG. 14C can be realized. In the driving shown in FIG. 14C, an apparent cycle is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input, so that driving frequency can be reduced, and thus power consumption can be reduced. Note that as has been described above, the period in which all the unit regions of the backlight are rewritten is not limited thereto, and a variety of periods can be used. Then, after rewriting shown by the group 1321 finishes, rewriting shown by the group 1323 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • In each of FIGS. 14B and 14D, transmittance of each pixel of the display panel is rewritten at the timing shown by a solid line. In this embodiment mode, rewriting is performed on pixels with the same vertical positions at the same timing, regardless of the horizontal position (line sequential driving). Note that the invention is not limited thereto as has been described above, and rewriting may be performed with dot sequential driving. In any case, it is important to match timings of rewriting the display panel and the backlight. Accordingly, difference between the states of the display panel and the backlight can be reduced; thus, defects of display, such as ghosting, can be reduced.
  • In FIG. 14B, a solid line 1311 schematically illustrates timing when all the pixels in the display panel are rewritten. To be exact, the timing should be stair shapes of the number of pixels in the vertical direction, similarly in FIG. 14A; however, in FIG. 14B, the timing is shown by the oblique line for simplification. In FIG. 14B, as shown by the solid line 1311, a period in which all the pixels of the display panel are rewritten is half the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. This is because the display panel is driven in accordance with driving of the backlight shown in FIG. 14A. Note that as has been described above, the period in which all the pixels of the display panel are rewritten is not limited thereto, and a variety of periods can be used. In any case, it is important to match timings of rewriting the display panel and the backlight. The reason is as described above. Then, after rewriting shown by the solid line 1311 finishes, the display panel is not driven until a period of half the cycle Tin of the input image data passes. Then, rewriting shown by a solid line 1313 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • In FIG. 14D, a solid line 1331 schematically illustrates timing when all the pixels in the display panel are rewritten. To be exact, the timing should be stair shapes of the number of pixels in the vertical direction, similarly in FIG. 14C; however, in FIG. 14D, the timing is shown by the oblique line for simplification. In FIG. 14D, as shown by the solid line 1331, a cycle in which all the pixels of the display panel are rewritten is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input. In the driving shown in FIG. 14D, the cycle is the same as the cycle Tin of the image data to be input, so that driving frequency can be reduced, and thus power consumption can be reduced. Note that as has been described above, the driving frequency is not limited thereto, and a variety of driving frequencies can be used. In any case, it is important to match timings of rewriting the display panel and the backlight. The reason is as described above. Then, after rewriting shown by the solid line 1331 finishes, rewriting shown by a solid line 1333 starts. Thereafter, these operations are repeated.
  • Note that in addition to the time when a period of half the cycle Tin of the input image data passes after driving shown by the group 1321 starts, the time when driving timing shown by the group 1322 in FIG. 14C starts can be a variety of timings, for example, the range shown by an arrow adjacent to the group 1322. The time when the driving timing shown by the group 1322 starts is preferably the time when a period of ¼ to ¾ times of the cycle Tin of the input image data passes after driving shown by the group 1321 starts. The time when the driving timing shown by the group 1322 starts is in this range, so that motion blur can be effectively reduced as well as flickers are reduced.
  • Note that whether timings of rewriting the backlight and the display panel correspond to each other can be determined from the fact that the solid line 1311 or 1331 crosses all of the solid lines included in the group 1301 or 1321 when FIGS. 14A and 14B or FIGS. 14C and 14D overlap with each other. It is important for the timings which can be said to correspond to each other to have a fixed range. In other words, since the timings of rewriting the backlight and the display panel have a fixed range of the timings which can be said to correspond to each other, it can be said that a margin in operation is large. That is, when the backlight and the display panel are operated at the timing shown in FIGS. 14A and 14B or FIGS. 14C and 14D, stability of the operation can be improved.
  • Note that although this embodiment mode is described with reference to various drawings, the contents (or part of the contents) described in each drawing can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with the contents (or part of the contents) described in another drawing. Further, much more drawings can be formed by combining each part with another part in the above-described drawings.
  • Similarly, the contents (or part of the contents) described in each drawing in this embodiment mode can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with the contents (or part of the contents) described in a drawing in another embodiment mode. Further, much more drawings can be formed by combining each part in each drawing in this embodiment mode with part of another embodiment mode.
  • Note that this embodiment mode shows examples of embodying, slightly transforming, partially modifying, improving, describing in detail, or applying the contents (or part of the contents) described in another embodiment mode, an example of related part thereof, or the like. Therefore, the contents described in another embodiment mode can be freely applied to, combined with, or replaced with this embodiment mode.
    • Embodiment Mode 4
  • In this embodiment mode, among methods of improving quality of images displayed on a display device, an example which is different from the methods described in Embodiment Modes 1 to 3 is described. Specifically, a method of improving quality of images displayed on a display device by using a backlight is described. More specifically, a method in which a period for displaying a blank image is provided for images displayed on the backlight in addition to an image in accordance with an image displayed on a display panel, and a period for displaying a blank image is provided for the images displayed on the display device in addition to an image in accordance with image data to be input; and a method in which the area of a backlight is divided into a plurality of regions and brightness of each of the plurality of regions is controlled in accordance with image data to be displayed are described.
  • A backlight and a display panel in the method described in this embodiment mode can be the backlight and the display panel described in Embodiment Mode 1. Although detailed description is omitted, characteristics and advantages of use of such backlight and display device are similar to those described in Embodiment Mode 1.
  • First, an image in this embodiment mode, which is displayed on an image display region of the display panel, is described. The image displayed on the image display region of the display panel has a period during which the image is displayed in accordance with image data to be input. The image data to be input has a given cycle, and an image displayed on the image display region is rewritten in accordance with the cycle. FIG. 15B illustrates change of the image displayed on the image display region with time passing. In the display panel shown in FIG. 15B, an image 1411 is displayed at a certain point.
